## Controversies

*Fallout 76* Power Armor [edition](special)(special edition) drew controversy upon release. Bethesda advertised that the edition would include a [canvas](canvas) [bag](duffel)(duffel bag), but a [nylon](nylon) one was included instead. Responding to customer complaints, Bethesda claimed that the bag had to be changed due to unavailability of materials, and initially stated the intention to take no action. The publisher received criticism for not making the change known beforehand, with *[Eurogamer](Eurogamer)* pointing out that the bag's description on Bethesda's website had only changed to read "nylon" after complaints had been submitted. Bethesda later offered affected customers free in-game currency of 500 atoms as compensation, equivalent to . Critics pointed out this amount of currency was not enough to purchase the in-game postman uniform (700 atoms), which includes a canvas bag. Additionally, it was discovered that Bethesda had produced a different *Fallout 76*–themed canvas bag and given them for free to [influencers](online)(Internet celebrity), further adding to the fan outrage. Bethesda announced on December 3, 2018, that they would be producing canvas bags for all owners of the Power Armor special edition, which were ultimately said to be shipping "in four to six months." In June 2019, the bags were delivered to customers.

A [breach](data)(data breach) occurred on December 5, 2018, when a [glitch](glitch) in Bethesda's [system](support)(Issue tracking system) revealed personal information of approximately 65 *Fallout 76* customers who had submitted a support ticket to receive the canvas bag. Users were able to open and close tickets of other customers and view personal information, including names, addresses, emails and partial credit card information. In a statement given to *[Technica](Ars)(Ars Technica)*, Bethesda said that the breach occurred via "an error with our customer support website" and that they are "investigating the incident and will provide additional updates as we learn more". The publisher clarified that the only information leaked were details that the support site would have requested, rather than credit card numbers or passwords, and that they would notify all affected customers.

In 2018, Bethesda partnered with the Silver Screen Bottling Company to create "Nuka Dark Rum", an alcoholic beverage based on the in-game "Nuka-Cola Dark" introduced in the *[4: Nuka-World](Fallout)(Fallout 4: Nuka-World)* [add-on](Downloadable content). The rum was available to be pre-ordered in August 2018 for . While its release was expected to coincide with the launch of *Fallout 76*, the rum was delayed and was shipped instead in late December 2018. Upon receiving it, fans criticized the fact that the rum bottle advertised, previously expected to be a bottle in the missile-like shape of the in-game Nuka-Cola item, had turned out to be a standard glass bottle encased in a large plastic cover. The rum's asking price of $80 was subsequently condemned from expectations that the design would be of high quality, since none of the marketing had stated what the bottles would be made of.

In September 2019, collectible "Nuka Cola"–themed *Fallout* helmets produced by Chronicle Collectibles, of which only 32 of the 20,000 manufactured were sold, were recalled by the [Consumer Product Safety Commission](U.S.)(U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission) due to containing high levels of mold and posing a health risk. No incidents or injuries were reported. [GameStop](GameStop), which sold the helmets, notified all customers who had purchased a helmet and offered them a full refund.

In June 2022, a *Kotaku* article published reports from ten anonymous former employees of Bethesda and its parent company [Media](ZeniMax)(ZeniMax Media) of severe mismanagement during *Fallout 76*s development. The reports claimed that [crunch](Crunch (video games)) had been enforced, leading to an "exodus" of senior developers from the company. The loss of staff led to Bethesda borrowing developers working on [Studios](Arkane)(Arkane Studios)' *[Redfall](Redfall)* and Bethesda's *[Starfield](Starfield (video game))* to assist with *Fallout 76*. Other alleged issues included technical problems with the game's design and engine, as well as these concerns being ignored by senior management. The sources expressed cynicism towards an improvement of working conditions at Bethesda (following their acquisition by Microsoft), saying "It would be great if something like [ABetterABK](ABK Workers Alliance) existed for Bethesda [...] But everyone is terrified...because [Bethesda] HR is super cutthroat."

The controversy involving the Fallout 76 Power Armor edition's physical item centered on the bag included in the edition. Bethesda had advertised that the edition would include a canvas bag, but instead, a nylon bag was included. This change was not disclosed beforehand, prompting customer complaints. Bethesda initially stated no action would be taken but then offered 500 free in-game atoms as compensation, which critics argued was insufficient. Additionally, it was discovered that Bethesda had produced canvas bags and given them for free to influencers only, which further upset fans. Eventually, Bethesda announced they would produce canvas bags for all owners of the Power Armor edition, shipping them months later.

There was also a related incident where a glitch in Bethesda's system exposed personal information of around 65 Fallout 76 customers who had submitted support tickets to request the canvas bag.

### 2018: Formation, EP, and tour

[[in 2018–2019](File:Boygenius.png|thumb|right|Boygenius)]

Bridgers has called the formation of the group "kind of an accident," wherein each of the members were simply fans of each other's work and then became friends. Both Dacus and Bridgers had opened for Baker on separate tours in 2016, and they all ran in similar circles as young up-and-coming performers navigating the [indie](Independent music) scene.

The three became close and shared their frustrations of constantly being compared to each other as "[in rock](women)(women in rock)" despite their considerably different musical styles. Dacus has commented that the idea of women in music "should not be remarkable whatsoever," with Bridgers adding, "it's not a genre." Each has spoken on the tendency of the music industry to pit women against each other, and the group was formed in part to reject this idea. "I hope people see the three of us and know there isn't competition," Dacus has said. "You don't have to compete with your contemporaries. You can make something good with people you admire."

Baker had joked to Dacus years before about a "pipe dream" that they could one day all form a band. The three decided to book a [tour](co-headlining)(Julien Baker and Phoebe Bridgers with Lucy Dacus Tour) in early 2018, and they originally planned to record a single or a [version](cover)(cover version) so that they could perform something together on stage. Upon meeting up that summer, however, they found themselves overwhelmed with ideas, and they ended up forming the band, writing, recording, and self-producing the *[Boygenius](Boygenius (EP))* [EP](Extended play) in four days, with the process involving almost exclusively women.

Each brought one full song and one incomplete idea with them to the group. They sought to create an environment free of the competitiveness and "bravado" they had often encountered in previous experiences, and they have remarked that the absence of adult men in the process proved significant, allowing them to relate to each other openly without constantly having to explain themselves. The record was met with universal acclaim from critics and audiences alike; it was named the 12th best album of 2018 by [Music](NPR)(NPR Music), despite being only an [EP](Extended play). Their subsequent [tour](Julien Baker and Phoebe Bridgers with Lucy Dacus Tour) that November saw them performing all across the U.S., as well as on *[Night with Seth Meyers](Late)(Late Night with Seth Meyers)* and the [Desk](Tiny)(List of Tiny Desk Concerts).
The indie rock supergroup boygenius was formed in 2018 by three musicians: Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, and Lucy Dacus.

O'Donnell was born in [D.C.](Washington,)(Washington, D.C.), the daughter of Noreen Bernadette (O'Kane) and Francis Lawrence O'Donnell, a [ medical doctor and](United States Army Medical Corps)  [Army](US)(US Army) officer.Stated on *[Your Roots](Finding)(Finding Your Roots)*, January 13, 2021 Her parents are both of Irish descent, with roots in [Derry](Derry), [Belfast](Belfast), and [Donegal](County Donegal) (meaning she is descended from both sides of the [Border](Irish)(Republic of Ireland–United Kingdom border)). Retrieved June 17, 2015. When she was 10, the family spent two years in [Seoul](Seoul), living in [Garrison](Yongsan)(Yongsan Garrison) as her father was assigned to work there. ## Production

### Box office

*Sonic the Hedgehog* grossed $149 million in the United States and Canada, and  in other territories, for a worldwide total of . It was the sixth-[film of 2020](highest-grossing)(2020 in film#Highest-grossing films), and the [superhero film of the year](highest-grossing)(List of highest-grossing superhero films), ending [Studios](Marvel)(Marvel Studios) decade-long run of having the highest-grossing film of the genre (from 2010 to 2019). The film's budget was estimated at being between $85 million and $90 million.

In the United States and Canada, the film was released alongside *[Island](Fantasy)(Fantasy Island (film))*, *[Photograph](The)(The Photograph (2020 film))*, and *[Downhill](Downhill (2020 film))*, and was initially projected to gross $40–50 million from 4,130 theaters in its four-day [Day](President's)(Washington's Birthday) opening weekend. After making $21 million on its first day (including $3 million from Thursday night previews), estimates were raised to $64 million. It went on to top the box office with a $58 million debut over the three-day weekend, and $70 million over the four, breaking *[Pikachu](Detective)(Detective Pikachu (film))*s record for the biggest opening weekend by a [game-based film](video)(List of films based on video games). It was also the fourth-best President's Day holiday weekend and Jim Carrey's second biggest opening weekend, behind *[Almighty](Bruce)(Bruce Almighty)* (2003). The success was attributed in part to the redesign of Sonic and the publicity it created, and the delayed release date, which meant it opened with less competition from other family films. Opening day audiences were 56% male and 44% female, with 70% under 25 years and 30% over 25 years. In its second weekend, *Sonic the Hedgehog* made $26.2 million and retained the top spot at the box office, bringing its ten-day domestic gross to . *Sonic the Hedgehog* made $16.3 million in its third weekend and was dethroned by newcomer *[Invisible Man](The)(The Invisible Man (2020 film))*. On March 14, 2020, it became the highest-grossing film based on a video game in US box office history, surpassing *Detective Pikachu*.

*Sonic the Hedgehog* was released in 40 countries during its three-day opening weekend, topping the international box office with . Its strongest international regions were Latin America and Europe, with its largest openings being  in Mexico,  in the United Kingdom,  in France,  in Germany, and  in Brazil. Worldwide, it made  over the three-day weekend and  over the four days. In its second weekend the film again topped the international box office with  from 56 countries for a ten-day overseas gross of , and topped the global box office again with  for a ten-day worldwide gross of . Its largest international markets in its first ten days were the United Kingdom (), Mexico (), and France (), retaining the top spot in these markets. The film opened in 16 new markets, led by a number-one debut in Russia (). The film was released in Japan on June 26, 2020, after being postponed from a previous March release due to the [pandemic](COVID-19)(COVID-19 pandemic), and debuted at No. 6 that weekend. In China, the release was also postponed due to the pandemic, eventually receiving a July 31 date and underperforming at the Chinese box office due to new pandemic-related theatre policies there.

In terms of box office admissions, the film sold 15,876,790 tickets in the United States and Canada (annual rank #3), 6,811,679 tickets in Mexico (annual #1), 893,634 tickets in Peru (annual #2), 468,697 tickets in Ecuador (annual #1), 67,230 tickets in the Dominican Republic (annual #2), 12,454,206 tickets in Europe (annual #3), 3,001,403 tickets in Brazil (annual #3), 698,500 tickets in China, 687,740 tickets in Argentina (annual #3), and 118,725 tickets in South Korea, for a combined |}} tickets sold in these territories.
The estimated budget for the 2020 Sonic the Hedgehog film was between $85 million and $90 million.

#### M270

* : [Army](Egyptian)(Egyptian Army) (42)

* : [Army](Hellenic)(Hellenic Army) (36) ATACMS operational.

* : [Ground Self-Defense Force](Japan)(Japan Ground Self-Defense Force) (99).

* : [Arabian Army](Saudi)(Saudi Arabian Army) (180)

* : [Army](Turkish)(Turkish Army) (12) ATACMS BLK 1A operational.

### Overview

The M270 MLRS weapons system is collectively known as the M270 MLRS Self-Propelled Loader/Launcher (SPLL). The SPLL is composed of three primary subsystems: the M269 Loader Launcher Module (LLM), which also houses the electronic Fire Control System, is mated to the M993 Carrier Vehicle.

[[Force XXI Armored Treatment and Transport Vehicle ATTP.jpg|thumb|Task Force XXI Armored Treatment and Transport Vehicle (ATTP)](File:Task)]

The M993 is the designation of the M987 carrier when it is used in the MLRS. The M987/M993 is a lengthened derivative of the [Fighting Vehicle](Bradley)(Bradley Fighting Vehicle) chassis. The ground contact length is increased from  to . Originally called the Fighting Vehicle System, the M987 chassis was designed to serve as the basis for many other vehicles. These included the XM1070 Electronic Fighting Vehicle, the M4 Command and Control Vehicle, the Armored Treatment and Transport Vehicle and the Forward Area Armored Logistics System (encompassing three vehicles including the XM1007 AFARV rearm vehicle.

The original GSRS plan called for 210 mm diameter rockets. After European allies became involved with the project, these were replaced with 227 mm rockets in order to accommodate the [mine](AT2)(AT2 mine).

[War](Cold)(Cold War) doctrine for the M270 was for the vehicles to spread out individually and hide until needed, then move to a firing position and launch their rockets, immediately move away to a reloading point, then move to a completely new hiding position near a different firing point. These [shoot-and-scoot](shoot-and-scoot) tactics were planned to avoid susceptibility to Soviet [fire](counterbattery)(counterbattery fire). One M270 firing 12 [M26](M26 artillery rocket) rockets would drop 7,728 bomblets, and one MLRS battery of nine launchers firing 108 rockets had the equivalent firepower of 33 battalions of cannon artillery.

The system can fire rockets or [ATACMS](MGM-140)(MGM-140 ATACMS) missiles, which are contained in interchangeable pods. Each pod contains six standard rockets or one guided ATACMS missile; the two types cannot be mixed. The LLM can hold two pods at a time, which are hand-loaded using an integrated winch system. All twelve rockets or two ATACMS missiles can be fired in under a minute. One launcher firing twelve rockets can completely blanket one square [kilometer](kilometer) with [submunitions](cluster bomb). A typical MLRS cluster salvo consisted of three M270 vehicles each firing all 12 rockets. With each rocket containing 644 [grenades](M77)(Dual-Purpose Improved Conventional Munition), the entire salvo would drop 23,184 grenades in the target area. However, with a two percent dud rate, that would leave approximately 400 undetonated bombs scattered over the area, which could endanger friendly troops and civilians.[After Cluster Bombs: Raining Nails](https://www.wired.com/2008/05/after-cluster-b/) , *Wired*, 30 May 2008

Production of the M270 ended in 2003, when a last batch was delivered to the [Army](Egyptian)(Egyptian Army). In 2003, the U.S. Army began low-rate production of the [HIMARS](M142)(M142 HIMARS). The HIMARS fires all of the munitions of the MLRS, but is based on the chassis of the [of Medium Tactical Vehicles](Family)(Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles). As of 2012, BAE Systems still had the capability to restart production of the MLRS.

In 2006, MLRS was upgraded to fire guided rounds. Phase I testing of a guided unitary round (XM31) was completed on an accelerated schedule in March 2006. Due to an Urgent Need Statement, the guided unitary round was quickly fielded and used in action in [Iraq](Iraq War).["Guided MLRS Unitary Rocket Successfully Tested"](http://www.mwjournal.com/journal/article.asp?HH_ID=AR_609) , *Microwave Journal*, Vol. 49, No. 3 (March 2006), p. 39. [Martin](Lockheed)(Lockheed Martin) also received a contract to convert existing M30 [Improved Conventional Munition (DPICM)](Dual-Purpose)(Dual-Purpose Improved Conventional Munition) GMLRS rockets to the XM31 unitary variant.

The M31 GMLRS Unitary rocket transformed the M270 into a point target artillery system for the first time. Due to [Positioning System](Global)(Global Positioning System) (GPS) guidance and a single  high-explosive warhead, the M31 could hit targets accurately with less chance of collateral damage while needing fewer rockets to be fired, reducing logistical requirements. The unitary warhead also made the MLRS able to be used in urban environments. The M31 had a dual-mode fuse with point detonation and delay options to defeat soft targets and lightly fortified bunkers respectively, with the upgraded M31A1 equipped with a multi-mode fuse adding a [proximity](proximity fuze) [airburst](air burst) mode for use against personnel in the open; proximity mode can be set for  Height Of Burst (HOB). The GMLRS has a minimum engagement range of  and can hit a target out to , impacting at a speed of Mach 2.5.[M31 GMLRS Unitary](http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/munitions/m31.htm) , Global security.[Precision Fires Rocket & Missile Systems](http://www.msl.army.mil/Pages/PFRMS/pgmr.html) , MSL Army. In 2009 Lockheed Martin announced that a GMLRS had been successfully test fired out to .

A German developmental artillery system, called the [Gun Module](Artillery)(Artillery Gun Module), has used the MLRS chassis on its developmental vehicles.

In 2012, a contract was issued to improve the armor of the M270s and improve the fire control to the standards of the M142 HIMARS. In June 2015, the M270A1 conducted tests of firing rockets after upgrades from the Improved Armored Cab project, which provides the vehicle with an enhanced armored cab and windows.[Improved Multiple Launch Rocket System tested at White Sands Missile Range](http://www.army.mil/article/153172/Improved_Multiple_Launch_Rocket_System_tested_at_White_Sands_Missile_Range/) , Army, 31 July 2015

In early March 2021, Lockheed announced they had successfully fired an extended-range version of the GMLRS out to , part of an effort to increase the rocket's range to . Later in March the ER-GMLRS was fired out to .

The original M270 launcher has the capacity to hold two rocket pods at a time. Each pod contains six standard rockets, allowing the launcher to fire a total of 12 rockets. The pods are interchangeable and hand-loaded using an integrated winch system. The launcher can also fire two guided ATACMS missiles, with each pod containing either six standard rockets or one ATACMS missile (not mixed in the same pod).

## Charitable activity

The company gives 5% of annual pretax earnings to causes in the areas in which it operates, including education and food banks. The Excellence in Education Awards are an annual charitable program maintained by H-E-B since 2000, in which teachers, administrators and schools in Texas are recognized, with awards totaling $500,000 in contributions in 2009.

H-E-B coordinated donations to relief efforts in the wake of a [plant fire and explosion](fertilizer)(West Fertilizer Company explosion) in [Texas](West,)(West, Texas). The company donated $50,000 to the [Red Cross](American)(American Red Cross) and launched a checkstand campaign benefiting the organization to get the community involved in the relief effort. The company said in a news release 100% of the donations from the campaign will support the American Red Cross's disaster relief efforts. H-E-B also activated its emergency response units, sending the H-E-B Eddie Garcia Mobile Kitchen and water tanker to West, including donations of meals and water to the victims and first responders.

In the aftermath of [Harvey](Hurricane)(Hurricane Harvey) in 2017, H-E-B donated $100,000 toward relief efforts. Its campaign drive for customer contributions totaled $1,000,000. In addition, H-E-B's Mobile Kitchen and Disaster Relief Units distributed 10,000 hot meals to volunteers and victims in the affected areas in Texas.

After the [Elementary School shooting](Robb)(Robb Elementary School shooting) in [Texas](Uvalde,)(Uvalde, Texas), on May 24, 2022, in which 19 children and two teachers were killed, H-E-B and the Butt family donated $10 million toward building a new school as founding donors. Initial participants joining the family include Texas architectural firm, Huckabee, and Texas general contractor, Joeris General Contractors.
H-E-B donates 5% of its annual pretax earnings to charitable causes in the areas where it operates.

## Cast and characters

* [Mitchell](Maia)(Maia Mitchell) as Callie Adams Foster (seasons 14, special guest season 5), a recent graduate of [UCSD](UCSD) Law School and Mariana's adopted sister. She leaves to join the [ACLU](American Civil Liberties Union) in Washington, D.C. in the second episode of season 4, though she has spoken to Mariana occasionally through web chat.

* [Ramirez](Cierra)(Cierra Ramirez) as Mariana Adams Foster, a software engineer and Callie's adopted sister who recently graduated from [MIT](Massachusetts Institute of Technology)

* Zuri Adele as Malika Williams, a bartender and political activist who lives with Callie and Mariana in the Coterie

* [Cola](Sherry)(Sherry Cola) as Alice Kwan, the building manager of The Coterie apartment building

* Tommy Martinez as Gael Martinez, a bisexual graphic designer and artist who falls for Callie

* [Bart](Roger)(Roger Bart) as Judge Curtis Wilson (seasons 1–2, guest season 3), a conservative judge for whom Callie worked as a clerk

* Emma Hunton as Davia Moss (season 2–present; recurring season 1), a body-positive influencer and teacher

* [Pence](Josh)(Josh Pence) as Dennis Cooper (season 2–present; recurring season 1), the oldest tenant in the Coterie who is an aspiring musician

* [Mirchoff](Beau)(Beau Mirchoff) as Jamie Hunter (seasons 3–4; recurring seasons 1–2; guest season 5), a lawyer and Callie's on-again-off-again boyfriend

* [Craig](Bryan)(Bryan Craig) as Joaquin Peréz (season 4–present), a mysterious new resident to the Coterie and investigative journalist who is looking for his estranged sister Jenna

* [Quintana](Priscilla)(Priscilla Quintana) as Isabella Tavez (season 4; recurring seasons 2–3; guest season 5), an aspiring actress and model

* [Stewart](Booboo)(Booboo Stewart) as Luca Ryusaki (season 5; recurring season 4), a homeless man whom Joaquin interviews for a story and is befriended by The Coterie inhabitants

### GRS Team

* [Krasinski](John)(John Krasinski) as Jack Silva, newest member of the team and former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs)

* [Badge Dale](James)(James Badge Dale) as [S. "Rone" Woods](Tyrone)(American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Tyrone S. Woods), commander of the GRS team and former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs)

* [Martini](Max)(Max Martini) as Mark "Oz" Geist, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps)

* [Fumusa](Dominic)(Dominic Fumusa) as John "Tig" Tiegen, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps)

* [Schreiber](Pablo)(Pablo Schreiber) as ["Tanto" Paronto](Kris)(Kris Paronto), team member and former [Army Ranger](US)(75th Ranger Regiment)

* [Denman](David)(David Denman) as Dave "Boon" Benton, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps) [Sniper](Scout)(United States Marine Corps Scout Sniper)

* [Stephens](Toby)(Toby Stephens) as ["Bub" Doherty](Glen)(American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Glen Doherty), GRS operator in Tripoli, former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs), and good friend of Woods and Silva

The main security team members in '13 Hours' belonged to the Global Response Staff (GRS). They were former members of elite military units including the United States Navy SEALs, United States Marine Corps, and the 75th Ranger Regiment of the Army Rangers.

### 2019–2020: *Pang*

In June 2019, Polachek released her debut single under her full name titled "[Door](Door (song))". In a press release for the single, Polachek announced that the single was the beginning of a new project, made mostly in collaboration with [Music](PC)(PC Music) member [L Harle](Danny)(Danny L Harle). Later in July, Polachek released two singles off of the project, titled "[of Tears](Ocean)(Ocean of Tears (song))" and "Parachute", and began to detail her then upcoming studio album *[Pang](Pang (album))* which was released on October 18, along with the fourth single "[Hot You're Hurting My Feelings](So)(So Hot You're Hurting My Feelings)". The album received critical acclaim and placed on many critics' end of the year lists. A remix album titled *Standing at the Gate: Remix Collection* was released on vinyl on April 16, 2021. In promotion, Polachek released five of the album's remixes as singles, as well as a cover of [Corrs](the)(the Corrs)' "[Breathless](Breathless (The Corrs song))".

In 2019, Polachek was a songwriter, along with [Jake](Yung)(Yung Jake), on the single "RIP Harambe" released by entrepreneur [Musk](Elon)(Elon Musk) about the [gorilla killed in 2016](captive)(Harambe). In 2020, Polachek featured on "[vita nuova](La)(La vita nuova (song))" by [and the Queens](Christine)(Christine and the Queens) and made a guest appearance in the short film around the EP of [same name](the)(La vita nuova (EP)). The song was later remixed by various producers including PC Music founder [G. Cook](A.)(A. G. Cook).

Caroline Polachek released the album "Pang" in 2019-2020, which received critical acclaim. Although the album was released in 2019, it includes the single "Bunny Is a Rider." # Pom Klementieff

*Revision ID: 1160114424 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T14:01:50Z*

---

| birth_place        = [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), Quebec, Canada

| nationality        = French

| education          = [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent)

| occupation         = Actress

| years_active       = 2007–present

| signature          = Pom Klementieff signature.svg

}}

**Pom Alexandra Klementieff** (; born 3 May 1986Additional  on 1 January 2018.) is a French actress. She was trained at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris and appeared in such French films as *[Easy Way](The)(The Easy Way (film))* (2008) and *[Night](Sleepless)(Sleepless Night (2011 film))* (2011), before making her American film debut in *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013). In 2019, she also made an appearance in *[Vipers](Striking)(Striking Vipers)*, the first episode of the fifth series of the anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition for her role as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019), *[Love and Thunder](Thor:)(Thor: Love and Thunder)* (2022), the television film *[Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special](The)(The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special)* (2022), and *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)* (2023).

## Early life

Klementieff was born in [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), [Quebec](Quebec), Canada to a Korean mother, Yu Ri Park, and Russian-French father Alexis Klementieff,The Canada Gazette, vol. 119, collected issues 40-43, 1985, p. 6445World Guide to Foreign Services, vol. 1, World Guides Internationale Publikationen, 1986, p. 261 who was working there as a consul with the government of France. She is a French citizen, but does not have Canadian citizenship because *[soli](jus)(jus soli)* does not apply to children of diplomats.Additional  on 7 July 2014. Her grandfather was Russian painter Eugene Klementieff (1901-c.1985). Her parents chose the name "Pom" because it is similar in pronunciation to the Korean words for both "spring" () and "tiger" (). Klementieff lived in Canada for one year before her family began traveling extensively due to her father's job. They lived in Japan and Ivory Coast before settling in France.

Klementieff's father died of cancer when she was five, and her mother had [schizophrenia](schizophrenia) and was unable to care for children, so Klementieff was raised by her paternal uncle and aunt. Her uncle, whom she described as "like [her] second father", died on her 18th birthday, and her older brother Namou died by suicide seven years later, on her 25th birthday. Klementieff briefly studied law in an undergraduate capacity after her uncle's death to appease her aunt, but did not find it appealing. She also worked as a waitress and saleswoman in France. She started acting at age 19 at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris. A few months into her education, she won a theater competition and two years of free classes with the school's top teachers.

[{'section_id': 'playground_games:playground_games', 'section_name': 'Playground Games'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:history', 'section_name': 'History'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:games_developed', 'section_name': 'Games developed'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:references', 'section_name': 'References'}, {'section_id': 'playground_games:external_links', 'section_name': 'External links'}]

## History

Playground Games was founded by Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams and Ralph Fulton; the studio was announced in November 2009, with its opening scheduled for early 2010. Playground Games announced their first project, *[Horizon](Forza)(Forza Horizon)*, in 2012. The title was developed in collaboration with [10 Studios](Turn)(Turn 10 Studios) and published by [Studios](Microsoft)(Microsoft Studios) for [360](Xbox)(Xbox 360) in October that year. The studio released *[Horizon 2](Forza)(Forza Horizon 2)* on Xbox 360 and [One](Xbox)(Xbox One) in September 2014, and *[Horizon 3](Forza)(Forza Horizon 3)* on Xbox One and [Windows](Microsoft)(Microsoft Windows) in September 2016.

In February 2014, Playground Games announced that they were forming a new development team focused on [game](mobile)(mobile game)s. In February 2017, the studio detailed plans to open a second studio, focusing on a non-racing open-world video game project. In November, they announced they had leased St. Albans House in Leamington Spa, which would provide the new studio with more than 17,000 square feet of office space. Expected headcounts for both studios were in excess of 200 people.

At [2018](E3)(E3 2018), [Microsoft](Microsoft) announced they had acquired Playground Games, which became part of Microsoft Studios (now known as Xbox Game Studios). At the same time, Microsoft Studios also announced *[Horizon 4](Forza)(Forza Horizon 4)*, which would be released on 2 October 2018, and that the studio was working on an unannounced AAA Open-World Action RPG project, later revealed to be in the *Fable* franchise.

In January 2022, it was reported that co-founder and [director](studio)(studio director) Gavin Raeburn left Playground Games to open his own studio, while [GM](General manager) Trevor Williams replaced him as studio head.
The three founders of Playground Games are Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams, and Ralph Fulton.

### 2001–2005: Breakthrough

Wood made her teenage debut as a leading film actress in 2001's *[Secrets](Little)(Little Secrets (2001 film))*, directed by [Treu](Blair)(Blair Treu), where she played 14-year-old aspiring concert violinist Emily Lindstrom. For that role, she was nominated for Best Leading Young Actress at the [Young Artist Awards](24th)(24th Young Artist Awards). Wood next played a supporting role in [Niccol](Andrew)(Andrew Niccol)'s 2002 satirical [fiction](science)(science fiction) film *[Simone](Simone (2002 film))*, which starred [Pacino](Al)(Al Pacino). That same year, Wood was recognized as One to Watch at the [Hollywood Awards](Young)(Young Hollywood Awards). }}

Wood's breakout movie role followed with [Hardwicke](Catherine)(Catherine Hardwicke)'s 2003 film *[Thirteen](Thirteen (2003 film))*. She starred as Tracy Louise Freeland, a young teen who sinks into a downward spiral of hard drugs, sex, and petty crime. Her performance garnered critical acclaim, earning her [Globe](Golden)(Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama) and [Actors Guild](Screen)(Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role) nominations for Best Lead Actress. During the time of *Thirteen*s release, Wood was featured on the cover of *[Vogue](Vogue (magazine))*, with the magazine naming her as one of the "It Girls" of Hollywood. She similarly appeared, along with eight other teen actresses, on the cover of *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*s Young Hollywood issue in July 2003. A supporting role opposite [Blanchett](Cate)(Cate Blanchett) and [Lee Jones](Tommy)(Tommy Lee Jones) in [Howard](Ron)(Ron Howard)'s *[Missing](The)(The Missing (2003 film))*, in which she played the kidnapped daughter Lilly Gilkeson, followed the same year, earning her a nomination for Best Leading Young Actress at the [Young Artist Awards](25th)(25th Young Artist Awards).

In 2005, Wood appeared opposite [Costner](Kevin)(Kevin Costner) and [Allen](Joan)(Joan Allen) in the [Binder](Mike)(Mike Binder)-directed *[Upside of Anger](The)(The Upside of Anger)*, a well-reviewed film in which Wood played Lavender "Popeye" Wolfmeyer, one of four sisters dealing with their father's absence. Her character also narrated the film. Wood's next two starring roles were in dark independent films. In the 2005 [Film Festival](Sundance)(Sundance Film Festival) Grand Jury Prize nominee *[Persuasion](Pretty)(Pretty Persuasion)*, a [comedy](black)(black comedy) focusing on the themes of [harassment in schools](sexual)(sexual harassment in education) and attitudes about women in media and society, Wood played Kimberly Joyce, a manipulative, sexually active high-schooler. One critic commented, "Wood does flip cynicism with such precise, easy rhythms and with such obvious pleasure in naughtiness that she's impossible to hate." [Jacobson](David)(David Jacobson (director))'s [neo-western](neo-western) *[in the Valley](Down)(Down in the Valley (film))* premiered later that year, in which Wood's character, Tobe, falls in love with an older man, played by [Norton](Edward)(Edward Norton), a cowboy who is at odds with modern society. Of her performance, it was written that "Wood conveys every bit of the adamant certainty and aching vulnerability inherent in late adolescence." Wood has commented on her sexually-themed roles, saying that she is not aiming for the "shock factor" in her film choices. Also in 2005, Wood starred in the music videos for [Eyes](Bright)(Bright Eyes (band))' "At the Bottom of Everything" and [Day](Green)(Green Day)'s "[Me Up When September Ends](Wake)(Wake Me Up When September Ends)".
In the 2001 film Little Secrets, Evan Rachel Wood's character, Emily Lindstrom, aspired to play the concert violin.

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.
The unicursal hexagram is an example of a specific instance of a more general shape discussed in Blaise Pascal's 1639 work titled "Mysticum Hexagrammum" (Hexagrammum Mysticum).

### Later life

[[File:Miyamoto Musashi Self-Portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Miyamoto Musashi, *[Self-portrait](Self-portrait),* c. 1640]]Twenty-one years later, in 1633, Musashi began staying with [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi), *[daimyō](Daimyo)* of [Castle](Kumamoto)(Kumamoto Castle), who had moved to the [Kumamoto](Kumamoto) fief and Kokura, to train and paint. While he engaged in very few duels; one would occur in 1634 at the arrangement of Lord Ogasawara, in which Musashi defeated a lance specialist by the name of [Matabei](Takada)(Takada Matabei). Musashi would officially become the retainer of the Hosokowa lords of Kumamoto in 1640. The *Niten Ki* records "[he] received from Lord Tadatoshi: 17 retainers, a stipend of 300 [koku](koku), the rank of *ōkumigashira* 大組頭, and [Castle](Chiba)(Chiba Castle) in Kumamoto as his residence."Toyota, p. 250

[[File:Tombe de Miyamoto Musashi à Ōhara, province de Mimasaka.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi's grave in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama), [of Mimasaka](province)(Mimasaka Province)]]

[[park.JPG|thumb|upright|The grave-marker of Miyamoto Musashi, in present-day Kumamoto Prefecture (熊本県)](File:Musashizuka)]

[[File:Miyamoto_Musashi_killing_a_giant_nue.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi kills a shark fish (Yamazame) in the mountains across the border of [Province](Echizen)(Echizen Province), by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

[[File:Musashi_ts_pic.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi in his prime, wielding two [bokken](bokken); woodblock print by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

In the second month of 1641, Musashi wrote a work called the *Hyoho Sanju Go* ("Thirty-five Instructions on Strategy") for [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi). This work overlapped and formed the basis for the later *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. This was the year that his adopted son, [Yoemon](Hirao)(Hirao Yoemon), became Master of Arms for the Owari fief. In 1642, Musashi suffered attacks of [neuralgia](neuralgia), foreshadowing his future ill-health. In 1643 he retired to a cave named *[Reigandō](Reigandō)* as a hermit to write *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. He finished it in the second month of 1645. On the twelfth of the fifth month, sensing his impending death, Musashi bequeathed his worldly possessions, after giving his manuscript copy of *The Book of Five Rings* to the younger brother of Terao Magonojo, his closest disciple. He died in Reigandō cave around June 13, 1645 (*[Shōhō](Shōhō) 2, 19th day of the 5th month*). The *Hyoho senshi denki* described his passing:

Miyamoto Musashi died of what is believed to be [cancer](thoracic)(lung cancer). He died peacefully after finishing the text *[Dokkōdō](Dokkōdō)* ("The Way of Walking Alone", or "The Way of Self-Reliance"), 21 precepts on self-discipline to guide future generations.

Miyamoto Musashi's death is believed to have been caused by lung cancer. He died peacefully around June 13, 1645, after finishing the text "Dokkōdō" ("The Way of Walking Alone" or "The Way of Self-Reliance").

## Early life

Kiernan Brennan Shipka was born in [Chicago](Chicago), [Illinois](Illinois), to John Young Shipka, a real estate developer, and Erin Ann Brennan. Shipka started taking [dancing](ballroom)(ballroom dancing) classes at the age of five, and was still attending classes as of March 2012. Her family relocated to [Angeles](Los)(Los Angeles), [California](California) when she was six to help with her acting career.

## Career

Cromwell's first television performance was in a 1974 episode of *[Rockford Files](The)(The Rockford Files)* playing Terry, a tennis instructor. A few weeks later, he began a recurring role as Stretch Cunningham on *[in the Family](All)(All in the Family)*. In 1975, he took his first lead role on television as Bill Lewis in the short-lived *[l Baltimore](Hot)(Hot l Baltimore)*, and appeared on *[M*A*S*H](M*A*S*H (TV series))* as Captain Leo Bardonaro in the episode "Last Laugh". A year later, he made his film debut in [Simon](Neil)(Neil Simon)'s classic detective spoof *[by Death](Murder)(Murder by Death)*. Cromwell portrayed four different characters in four episodes of *[Miller](Barney)(Barney Miller)* (1977-1981).

In 1977 he appeared in [Company](Three's)(Three's Company) episode- "Chrissy's Night Out" as Detective Lannigan.

In 1980, Cromwell guest-starred in the two-part episode "Laura Ingalls Wilder" of the long-running television series *[House on the Prairie](Little)(Little House on the Prairie (TV series))*. He played Harve Miller, one of Almanzo Wilder's old friends.

While Cromwell continued with regular television work throughout the 1980s, he made appearances in films with supporting roles in *[Tank](Tank (film))* and *[of the Nerds](Revenge)(Revenge of the Nerds)* (both 1984). He guest starred on the sitcom *[Court](Night)(Night Court)*, playing a mental patient, along with [Peter Hall](Kevin)(Kevin Peter Hall). He had starring roles in the critically acclaimed films *[Babe](Babe (film))* (1995), *[People vs. Larry Flynt](The)(The People vs. Larry Flynt)* (1996), *[Education of Little Tree](The)(The Education of Little Tree (film))* (1997), *[Confidential](L.A.)(L.A. Confidential (film))* (1997), *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999), ''[General's Daughter](The)(The General's Daughter (film))*, (1999) and *[Falling on Cedars](Snow)(Snow Falling on Cedars (film))'' (1999). Cromwell's first *[Trek](Star)(Star Trek)* role was on *[Trek: The Next Generation](Star)(Star Trek: The Next Generation)* in 1990, in the season 3 episode "[Hunted](The)(The Hunted (Star Trek: The Next Generation))", followed by the 1993 episode "[Part 1](Birthright,)(Birthright (Star Trek: The Next Generation))" as Jaglom Shrek. He also played Dr. [Cochrane](Zefram)(Zefram Cochrane) in *[Trek: First Contact](Star)(Star Trek: First Contact)* (1996), the *[Trek: Enterprise](Star)(Star Trek: Enterprise)* pilot episode "[Bow](Broken)(Broken Bow (Star Trek: Enterprise))", and the 2022 *[Trek: Lower Decks](Star)(Star Trek: Lower Decks)* season 3 premiere episode, "Grounded". The *Star Trek: Enterprise* episode "[a Mirror, Darkly](In)(In a Mirror, Darkly)" reused some of the *First Contact* footage. Cromwell appeared in another *Star Trek* role on the television series *[Space Nine](Deep)(Deep Space Nine)*, in the episode "[Down](Starship)(Starship Down)" as Hanok. He also voiced the Colonel in [DreamWorks](DreamWorks Animation)' *[Stallion of the Cimarron](Spirit:)(Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron)*.

Cromwell's role as newspaper tycoon [Randolph Hearst](William)(William Randolph Hearst) in the television film *[281](RKO)(RKO 281)* earned him an [Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Television Movie](Emmy)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor – Miniseries or a Movie). The following year, he received his second Emmy Award nomination for playing Bishop Lionel Stewart on the [NBC](NBC) medical drama series *[ER](ER (TV series))*. In 2004, he guest-starred as former President D. Wire Newman in *[West Wing](The)(The West Wing)* episode "[Stormy Present](The)(The Stormy Present)". From 2003 to 2005, Cromwell played [Sibley](George)(George Sibley (Six Feet Under)) in the [HBO](HBO) drama series *[Feet Under](Six)(Six Feet Under (TV series))*, which earned him his third Emmy Award nomination in 2003. Along with the rest of his castmates, he was also nominated for two [Actors Guild Awards for Best Ensemble in a Drama Series](Screen)(Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series) in 2005 and 2006. The following year, Cromwell played [Philip, Duke of Edinburgh](Prince)(Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh) in *[Queen](The)(The Queen (2006 film))* (2006), that earned [Mirren](Helen)(Helen Mirren) an [Award for Best Actress](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Actress). He also guest starred as [Bauer](Phillip)(List of 24 characters#Phillip Bauer), father of lead character [Jack](Jack Bauer), in the [season](sixth)(24 (season 6)) of the [Fox](Fox Broadcasting Company) thriller drama series *[24](24 (TV series))*.

In October 2007, Cromwell played the lead role of James Tyrone Sr. in the [Theatre Company](Druid)(Druid Theatre Company)'s production of [O'Neill](Eugene)(Eugene O'Neill)'s ''[Day's Journey into Night](Long)(Long Day's Journey into Night)'', at the [in Dublin](Gaiety)(Gaiety Theatre, Dublin) as part of the [Bank Dublin Theatre Festival's](Ulster)(Dublin Theatre Festival) 50th Anniversary.[Gaiety Theatre Dublin, Ireland – Irish Theatre](http://www.gaietytheatre.ie/shows/LongDaysJourneyIntoNight.htm)  That same year he received the King Vidor Memorial Award from the [Luis Obispo International Film Festival](San)(San Luis Obispo International Film Festival) for his artistic achievements in film. Cromwell played [H. W. Bush](George)(George H. W. Bush) in [Stone](Oliver)(Oliver Stone)'s *[W.](W. (film))* (2008), that chronicles the rise to power of [son](Bush's)(George W. Bush) up until the [invasion of Iraq](2003)(2003 invasion of Iraq). Cromwell also provided the voice of the main villain Professor Robert Callaghan/Yokai in the Disney movie *[Hero 6](Big)(Big Hero 6 (film))*.

In 2015, Cromwell executive produced the documentary *[Threat](Imminent)(Imminent Threat)* which tackles the War on Terror's impact on civil liberties.

In 2016 Cromwell starred in [HBO](HBO)'s series *[Young Pope](The)(The Young Pope)* alongside [Law](Jude)(Jude Law) and [Keaton](Diane)(Diane Keaton). In 2018, he appeared in [HBO](HBO)'s *[Succession](Succession (TV series))*, and [Starz](Starz)'s *[Counterpart](Counterpart (TV series))*.

In 2020, Cromwell starred in the Australian comedy-drama film *[Too Late](Never)(Never Too Late (2020 film))*.Maddox, Garry (16 April 2019) [Life is still busy over 70 for stars of new 'triumph over ageing' film](https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/life-is-still-busy-over-70-for-stars-of-new-triumph-over-ageing-film-20190408-p51bxg.html), *[Sydney Morning Herald](The)(The Sydney Morning Herald)*. Retrieved 20 February 2020. Cromwell starred in *[Buffalo](Operation)(Operation Buffalo (TV series))*, an Australian television comedy-drama series about the atomic bomb tests in outback Australia, which screened on [ABC](ABC TV (Australian TV network)) from 31 May 2020.

He is currently featured in the [Max](HBO)(HBO Max) show *[Julia](Julia (2022 TV series))*, as Julia Child's father, John McWilliams.

In 2021, Cromwell executive produced the psychedelic comedy *[Hollywoodland](Mondo)(Mondo Hollywoodland)*, directed by Janek Ambros, who also directed *Imminent Threat*.
James Cromwell played the character George Sibley in the HBO drama series "Six Feet Under."

## Early life

He was born Alfredo Molina on 24 May 1953 in the [Paddington](Paddington) district of London. His father, Esteban J. Molina, was a Spanish immigrant from [Murcia](Murcia), who came to England in 1939, and worked as a waiter and chauffeur. His mother, Giovanna (née Bonelli), was an Italian immigrant who moved to Britain after [War II](World)(World War II), and who cleaned rooms in a hotel, and worked as a cook and housekeeper. Molina grew up in a working-class district in [Hill](Notting)(Notting Hill) that was inhabited by many other immigrant families. He attended a Roman Catholic secondary school there. He decided to become an actor after seeing *[Spartacus](Spartacus (film))* at the age of nine, and attended the [School of Music and Drama](Guildhall)(Guildhall School of Music and Drama), as well as auditioning for and becoming a member of the [Youth Theatre](National)(National Youth Theatre). At the age of 21, he changed his name to Alfred, at the urging of his first agent.
Alfred Molina attended the Guildhall School of Music and Drama.

### Origins

The origins of rock and roll have been fiercely debated by commentators and historians of music. There is general agreement that it arose in the Southern United States – a region that would produce most of the major early rock and roll acts – through the meeting of various influences that embodied a merging of the African musical tradition with European instrumentation.M. T. Bertrand, *Race, Rock, and Elvis: Music in American Life* (University of Illinois Press, 2000), pp. 21–22. [migration of many former slaves and their descendants to major urban centers](The)(Second Great Migration (African American)) such as [Louis](St.)(St. Louis), [Memphis](Memphis, Tennessee), [York City](New)(New York City), [Detroit](Detroit), [Chicago](Chicago), [Cleveland](Cleveland), and [Buffalo](Buffalo, New York) meant that black and white residents were living in close proximity in larger numbers than ever before, and as a result heard each other's music and even began to emulate each other's fashions.R. Aquila, *That old-time rock & roll: a chronicle of an era, 1954–1963* (Chicago: University of Illinois Press, 2000), pp. 4–6.J. M. Salem, ''The late, great Johnny Ace and the transition from R & B to rock 'n' roll Music in American life* (University of Illinois Press, 2001), p. 4. Radio stations that made white and black forms of music available to both groups, the development and spread of the [record](gramophone)(gramophone record), and African-American musical styles such as [jazz](jazz) and [swing](Swing music) which were taken up by white musicians, aided this process of "cultural collision".M. T. Bertrand, *Race, rock, and Elvis Music in American life'' (University of Illinois Press, 2000), p. 99.

[[File:Chuck Berry 1957.jpg|thumb|right|[Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry) in 1957]]

The immediate roots of rock and roll lay in the [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues), then called "[music](race)(race music)", in combination with either boogie-woogie and shouting gospel or with [music](country)(country music) of the 1940s and 1950s. Particularly significant influences were jazz, [blues](blues), [gospel](Gospel music), country, and [folk](folk music). Commentators differ in their views of which of these forms were most important and the degree to which the new music was a re-branding of African-American [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues) for a white market, or a new hybrid of black and white forms.A. Bennett, *Rock and Popular Music: Politics, Policies, Institutions* (Routledge, 1993), pp. 236–238.K. Keightley, "Reconsidering rock", in S. Frith, W. Straw and J. Street, eds, *The Cambridge Companion to Pop and Rock* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001), p. 116.N. Kelley, *R&B, Rhythm and Business: The Political Economy of Black Music* (Akashic Books, 2005), p. 134.

[[File:Roll Em Pete.jpg|alt=A picture of the 7" single for "Roll 'Em Pete"|thumb|161x161px|[Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner) and [Johnson](Pete)(Pete Johnson (musician))'s record "['Em Pete](Roll)(Roll 'Em Pete)" is regarded as a precursor to rock and roll.]]

Contradicting Larry Birnbaum, the author of ''Before Elvis: The Prehistory of Rock 'n' Roll'', and notwithstanding early forms of white rock and roll then called "country boogie", musicologist and rock historian [Blum](Bruno)(Bruno Blum) argues that early, fully-formed rock and roll music really surged in America at least as early as 1945, but was segregated, thus making it unavailable to the general public and widely undocumented. According to Blum, true rock tracks from the 1940s included "Rock Woogie" by Jim Wynn's Bobalibans (1945), "Rockin' the House" by Memphis Slim and the House Rockers (1946), "Aladdin Boogie" by Amos Milburn (1947), "Rock and Rye" by Jimmy McCracklin (1947), "We're Gonna Rock" (1947) and "Rock and Roll" (1948) by Wild Bill Moore, and many others. His discussion of the topic is as follows:, text in both English pp17-18 and French pp 3-4.

The music was also called "blues" (*My Baby Left Me* by [Crudup](Arthur)(Arthur Crudup)), "rhythm music" ("Hambone" by [Saunders](Red)(Red Saunders (musician))), "rhythm and blues" ("Honey Hush" by [Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner)), "R&B" (the abbreviation of "rhythm and blues" and the name given to "black" music styles in the charts of Billboard magazine post-summer 1949), "jump blues" ("Rock Around the Clock" by [Singer](Hal)(Hal Singer)), "big beat", "rock 'n' roll" or "race music", was the label used by the press and Billboard in particular.}}

In the 1930s, [jazz](jazz), and particularly [swing](Swing music), both in urban-based dance bands and blues-influenced country swing ([Rodgers](Jimmie)(Jimmie Rodgers), [Mullican](Moon)(Moon Mullican) and other similar singers), were among the first music to present African-American sounds for a predominantly white audience.E. Wald, *How the Beatles Destroyed Rock N Roll: An Alternative History of American Popular Music* (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2009), pp. 111–125. One particularly noteworthy example of a jazz song with recognizably rock and roll elements is [Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner) with pianist [Johnson](Pete)(Pete Johnson (musician))'s 1939 single "['Em Pete](Roll)(Roll 'Em Pete)", which is regarded as an important precursor of rock and roll.[Tosches](Nick)(Nick Tosches), ''Unsung Heroes of Rock 'n' Roll*, Secker & Warburg, 1991, Peter J. Silvester, *A Left Hand Like God: a history of boogie-woogie piano* (1989), .M. Campbell, ed., *Popular Music in America: And the Beat Goes on* (Cengage Learning, 3rd edn, 2008), p. 99.  The 1940s saw the increased use of blaring horns (including saxophones), shouted lyrics and boogie-woogie beats in jazz-based music. During and immediately after [War II](World)(World War II), with shortages of fuel and limitations on audiences and available personnel, large jazz bands were less economical and tended to be replaced by smaller combos, using guitars, bass and drums.P. D. Lopes, *The rise of a jazz art world* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), p. 132 In the same period, particularly on the [Coast](West)(West Coast of the United States) and in the [Midwest](Midwestern United States), the development of [blues](jump)(jump blues), with its guitar riffs, prominent beats and shouted lyrics, prefigured many later developments. In the documentary film *[Hail! Rock 'n' Roll](Hail!)(Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll)*, [Richards](Keith)(Keith Richards) proposes that [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry) developed his brand of rock and roll by transposing the familiar two-note lead line of jump blues piano directly to the electric guitar, creating what is instantly recognizable as rock guitar. This proposal by Richards neglects the black guitarists who did the same thing before Berry, such as [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter),Robert Palmer, "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, Present Tense, Duke University Press, 1992, p. 19. . [Brown](Gatemouth)(Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown),*Encyclopedia of Louisiana Musicians: Jazz, Blues, Cajun, Creole, Zydeco, Swamp Pop, and Gospel*. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. p. 57. . and the originator of the style, [Walker](T-Bone)(T-Bone Walker).Dance, Helen Oakley, "Walker, Aaron Thibeaux (T-Bone)", *The Handbook of Texas Online*. Denton: Texas State Historical Association. [boogie](Country)(Country boogie) and [electric blues](Chicago)(Chicago blues) supplied many of the elements that would be seen as characteristic of rock and roll. Inspired by [blues](electric)(electric blues), Chuck Berry introduced an aggressive guitar sound to rock and roll, and established the electric guitar as its centerpiece,Michael Campbell & James Brody, *Rock and Roll: An Introduction*, [pp. 110–111](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA110)  adapting his rock band instrumentation from the basic blues band instrumentation of a lead guitar, second chord instrument, bass and drums.Michael Campbell & James Brody, [*Rock and Roll: An Introduction''](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA80), , pp. 80–81. In 2017, [Christgau](Robert)(Robert Christgau) declared that "Chuck Berry did in fact invent rock 'n' roll", explaining that this artist "came the closest of any single figure to being the one who put all the essential pieces together".

Rock and roll arrived at a time of considerable technological change, soon after the development of the electric guitar, [amplifier](amplifier) and [microphone](microphone), and the [rpm record](45)(45 rpm record). There were also changes in the record industry, with the rise of independent labels like [Atlantic](Atlantic records), [Sun](Sun Records) and [Chess](Chess Records) servicing [audiences](niche)(niche market) and a similar rise of radio stations that played their music. It was the realization that relatively affluent white teenagers were listening to this music that led to the development of what was to be defined as rock and roll as a distinct genre. Because the development of rock and roll was an evolutionary process, no single record can be identified as unambiguously "the first" rock and roll record.[Dawson](Jim)(Jim Dawson) and Steve Propes, ''[Was The First Rock'n'Roll Record](What)(iarchive:whatwasfirstrock0000daws)'', 1992,  Contenders for the title of "[rock and roll record](first)(first rock and roll record)" include [Rosetta Tharpe](Sister)(Sister Rosetta Tharpe)'s "[Things Happening Every Day](Strange)(Strange Things Happening Every Day)" (1944), "[All Right](That's)(That's All Right)" by [Crudup](Arthur)(Arthur Crudup) (1946),  "[It On Over](Move)(Move It On Over (song))" by [Williams](Hank)(Hank Williams) (1947), "[Fat Man](The)(The Fat Man (song))" by [Domino](Fats)(Fats Domino) (1949), [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter)'s "[Awhile](Rock)(Rock Awhile)" (1949),[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, p. 19.  and [Preston](Jimmy)(Jimmy Preston)'s "[the Joint](Rock)(Rock the Joint)" (1949) (later [covered](cover version) by [Haley & His Comets](Bill)(Bill Haley & His Comets) in 1952),

"[88](Rocket)(Rocket 88)" by [Brenston](Jackie)(Jackie Brenston) and his Delta Cats ([Turner](Ike)(Ike Turner) and his band [Kings of Rhythm](The)(Kings of Rhythm) and sung by Brenston), was recorded by [Phillips](Sam)(Sam Phillips) in March 1951. This is often cited as the first rock n' roll record.M. Campbell, ed., *Popular Music in America: and the Beat Goes on* (Boston, Massachusetts: Cengage Learning, 3rd ed., 2008), , pp. 157–8. In an interview however, Ike Turner offered this comment: "I don't think that 'Rocket 88' is rock 'n' roll. I think that 'Rocket 88' is R&B, but I think 'Rocket 88' is the cause of rock and roll existing".

[[File:BillHaley.JPG|upright=1.05|thumb|[Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley) and his Comets performing in the 1954 Universal International film *Round Up of Rhythm*]]

In terms of its wide cultural impact across society in the US and elsewhere, [Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley (musician))'s "[Around the Clock](Rock)(Rock Around the Clock)", recorded in April 1954 but not a commercial success until the following year, is generally recognized as an important milestone, but it was preceded by many recordings from earlier decades in which elements of rock and roll can be clearly discerned.Robert Palmer, "Rock Begins", in *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone) Illustrated History of Rock and Roll*, 1976/1980,  (UK edition), pp. 3–14.

Journalist [Petridis](Alexis)(Alexis Petridis) argued that neither Haley's "Rock Around the Clock" nor Presley's version of "That's Alright Mama" heralded a new genre: "They were simply the first white artists' interpretations of a sound already well-established by black musicians almost a decade before. It was a raucous, driving, unnamed variant of rhythm and blues that came complete with lyrics that talked about rocking".

Other artists with early rock and roll hits included [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry), [Diddley](Bo)(Bo Diddley), [Richard](Little)(Little Richard), [Lee Lewis](Jerry)(Jerry Lee Lewis), and [Vincent](Gene)(Gene Vincent). Chuck Berry's 1955 classic "[Maybellene](Maybellene)" in particular features a [distorted](distortion (music)) [guitar](electric)(electric guitar) solo with warm [overtone](overtone)s created by his small [amplifier](valve)(valve amplifier). However, the use of distortion was predated by electric blues guitarists such as [Hill Louis](Joe)(Joe Hill Louis), [Slim](Guitar)(Guitar Slim),. [Johnson](Willie)(Willie Johnson (guitarist)) of [Wolf](Howlin')(Howlin' Wolf)'s band, and [Hare](Pat)(Pat Hare); the latter two also made use of distorted [chord](power)(power chord)s in the early 1950s.[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, pp. 24–27. . Also in 1955, Bo Diddley introduced the "[Diddley beat](Bo)(Bo Diddley beat)" and a unique electric guitar style,P. Buckley, *The rough guide to rock* (Rough Guides, 3rd ed., 2003), p. 21. influenced by [African](Music of Africa) and [music](Afro-Cuban)(Afro-Cuban music) and in turn influencing many later artists.

Lopes, *The rise of a jazz art world* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), p. 132 In the same period, particularly on the [Coast](West)(West Coast of the United States) and in the [Midwest](Midwestern United States), the development of [blues](jump)(jump blues), with its guitar riffs, prominent beats and shouted lyrics, prefigured many later developments. In the documentary film *[Hail! Rock 'n' Roll](Hail!)(Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll)*, [Richards](Keith)(Keith Richards) proposes that [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry) developed his brand of rock and roll by transposing the familiar two-note lead line of jump blues piano directly to the electric guitar, creating what is instantly recognizable as rock guitar. This proposal by Richards neglects the black guitarists who did the same thing before Berry, such as [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter),Robert Palmer, "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, Present Tense, Duke University Press, 1992, p. 19. . [Brown](Gatemouth)(Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown),*Encyclopedia of Louisiana Musicians: Jazz, Blues, Cajun, Creole, Zydeco, Swamp Pop, and Gospel*. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. p. 57. . and the originator of the style, [Walker](T-Bone)(T-Bone Walker).Dance, Helen Oakley, "Walker, Aaron Thibeaux (T-Bone)", *The Handbook of Texas Online*. Denton: Texas State Historical Association. [boogie](Country)(Country boogie) and [electric blues](Chicago)(Chicago blues) supplied many of the elements that would be seen as characteristic of rock and roll. Inspired by [blues](electric)(electric blues), Chuck Berry introduced an aggressive guitar sound to rock and roll, and established the electric guitar as its centerpiece,Michael Campbell & James Brody, *Rock and Roll: An Introduction*, [pp. 110–111](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA110)  adapting his rock band instrumentation from the basic blues band instrumentation of a lead guitar, second chord instrument, bass and drums.Michael Campbell & James Brody, [*Rock and Roll: An Introduction''](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA80), , pp. 80–81. In 2017, [Christgau](Robert)(Robert Christgau) declared that "Chuck Berry did in fact invent rock 'n' roll", explaining that this artist "came the closest of any single figure to being the one who put all the essential pieces together".

Rock and roll arrived at a time of considerable technological change, soon after the development of the electric guitar, [amplifier](amplifier) and [microphone](microphone), and the [rpm record](45)(45 rpm record). There were also changes in the record industry, with the rise of independent labels like [Atlantic](Atlantic records), [Sun](Sun Records) and [Chess](Chess Records) servicing [audiences](niche)(niche market) and a similar rise of radio stations that played their music. It was the realization that relatively affluent white teenagers were listening to this music that led to the development of what was to be defined as rock and roll as a distinct genre. Because the development of rock and roll was an evolutionary process, no single record can be identified as unambiguously "the first" rock and roll record.[Dawson](Jim)(Jim Dawson) and Steve Propes, ''[Was The First Rock'n'Roll Record](What)(iarchive:whatwasfirstrock0000daws)'', 1992,  Contenders for the title of "[rock and roll record](first)(first rock and roll record)" include [Rosetta Tharpe](Sister)(Sister Rosetta Tharpe)'s "[Things Happening Every Day](Strange)(Strange Things Happening Every Day)" (1944), "[All Right](That's)(That's All Right)" by [Crudup](Arthur)(Arthur Crudup) (1946),  "[It On Over](Move)(Move It On Over (song))" by [Williams](Hank)(Hank Williams) (1947), "[Fat Man](The)(The Fat Man (song))" by [Domino](Fats)(Fats Domino) (1949), [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter)'s "[Awhile](Rock)(Rock Awhile)" (1949),[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, p. 19.  and [Preston](Jimmy)(Jimmy Preston)'s "[the Joint](Rock)(Rock the Joint)" (1949) (later [covered](cover version) by [Haley & His Comets](Bill)(Bill Haley & His Comets) in 1952),

"[88](Rocket)(Rocket 88)" by [Brenston](Jackie)(Jackie Brenston) and his Delta Cats ([Turner](Ike)(Ike Turner) and his band [Kings of Rhythm](The)(Kings of Rhythm) and sung by Brenston), was recorded by [Phillips](Sam)(Sam Phillips) in March 1951. This is often cited as the first rock n' roll record.M. Campbell, ed., *Popular Music in America: and the Beat Goes on* (Boston, Massachusetts: Cengage Learning, 3rd ed., 2008), , pp. 157–8. In an interview however, Ike Turner offered this comment: "I don't think that 'Rocket 88' is rock 'n' roll. I think that 'Rocket 88' is R&B, but I think 'Rocket 88' is the cause of rock and roll existing".

[[File:BillHaley.JPG|upright=1.05|thumb|[Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley) and his Comets performing in the 1954 Universal International film *Round Up of Rhythm*]]

In terms of its wide cultural impact across society in the US and elsewhere, [Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley (musician))'s "[Around the Clock](Rock)(Rock Around the Clock)", recorded in April 1954 but not a commercial success until the following year, is generally recognized as an important milestone, but it was preceded by many recordings from earlier decades in which elements of rock and roll can be clearly discerned.Robert Palmer, "Rock Begins", in *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone) Illustrated History of Rock and Roll*, 1976/1980,  (UK edition), pp. 3–14.

Journalist [Petridis](Alexis)(Alexis Petridis) argued that neither Haley's "Rock Around the Clock" nor Presley's version of "That's Alright Mama" heralded a new genre: "They were simply the first white artists' interpretations of a sound already well-established by black musicians almost a decade before. It was a raucous, driving, unnamed variant of rhythm and blues that came complete with lyrics that talked about rocking".

Other artists with early rock and roll hits included [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry), [Diddley](Bo)(Bo Diddley), [Richard](Little)(Little Richard), [Lee Lewis](Jerry)(Jerry Lee Lewis), and [Vincent](Gene)(Gene Vincent). Chuck Berry's 1955 classic "[Maybellene](Maybellene)" in particular features a [distorted](distortion (music)) [guitar](electric)(electric guitar) solo with warm [overtone](overtone)s created by his small [amplifier](valve)(valve amplifier). However, the use of distortion was predated by electric blues guitarists such as [Hill Louis](Joe)(Joe Hill Louis), [Slim](Guitar)(Guitar Slim),. [Johnson](Willie)(Willie Johnson (guitarist)) of [Wolf](Howlin')(Howlin' Wolf)'s band, and [Hare](Pat)(Pat Hare); the latter two also made use of distorted [chord](power)(power chord)s in the early 1950s.[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, pp. 24–27. . Also in 1955, Bo Diddley introduced the "[Diddley beat](Bo)(Bo Diddley beat)" and a unique electric guitar style,P. Buckley, *The rough guide to rock* (Rough Guides, 3rd ed., 2003), p. 21. influenced by [African](Music of Africa) and [music](Afro-Cuban)(Afro-Cuban music) and in turn influencing many later artists.

Chuck Berry is often known as the "Architect of Rock and Roll." He is credited with developing a distinctive style of rock and roll guitar and was one of the pioneering figures in the genre. His 1955 classic "Maybellene" features a distinctive guitar solo and he established the electric guitar as the centerpiece of rock and roll music. Critics and historians have noted that Chuck Berry came the closest of any single figure to putting all the essential pieces of rock and roll together.

## Early life

Emmanuelle Grey Rossum was born on September 12, 1986, in New York City. She is the only child of Cheryl Rossum, a single mother who worked as a corporate photographer. Her parents separated while her mother was pregnant, and as of 2007, she had met her father only twice.

Rossum's mother is Jewish of [Jewish](Russian)(History of the Jews in Russia) descent, and her father is [Protestant](Protestant) of English and Dutch ancestry. Rossum identifies as Jewish and has stated that her mother instilled in her the "Jewish code of ethics and morals". She was named for her great-grandfather, whose first name was Emanuel, using the feminine spelling.

Upon singing "[Birthday](Happy)(Happy Birthday to You)" in all 12 keys,Joffe, Jessica. "Emmy Rossum: Hollywood's newest It Girl." Glamour: September 2006. p 326-7, 392 Rossum was welcomed to join the [Opera](Metropolitan)(Metropolitan Opera) Children's Chorus by chorus director Elena Doria at age seven. Over the course of five years she sang onstage with the chorus and had the chance to perform with singers such as [Domingo](Plácido)(Plácido Domingo) and [Pavarotti](Luciano)(Luciano Pavarotti). For anywhere from $5 to $10 a night, Rossum sang in six languages in 20 operas, including *[bohème](La)(La bohème)*, *[Turandot](Turandot)*, a [Hall](Carnegie)(Carnegie Hall) presentation of *[damnation de Faust](La)(La damnation de Faust)*, and ''[ A Midsummer Night's Dream](A Midsummer Night's Dream (opera) )''."It's Evening in America". *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*. May 2012. Page 152. She also worked under the direction of [Zeffirelli](Franco)(Franco Zeffirelli) in *[Carmen](Carmen)*.

An increasing interest in pursuing acting led to taking classes with Flo Salant Greenberg of [New Actors Workshop](The)(The New Actors Workshop) in New York City. She has also worked with acting coach Terry Knickerbocker.

Rossum attended the [School](Spence)(Spence School), a private school in [Manhattan](Manhattan), before dropping out to pursue career opportunities. She received her high school diploma at fifteen years old via online-extension courses offered by [University](Stanford)(Stanford University)'s [Program for Gifted Youth](Education)(Education Program for Gifted Youth) (EPGY). She enrolled at [University](Columbia)(Columbia University), studying French, art history and philosophy.
Emmy Rossum attended Columbia University where she studied French, art history, and philosophy.

The actual pronunciation in [Arabic](Literary)(Modern Standard Arabic) varies regionally. The first vowel varies from  to , while the second vowel varies from  to  to . For example, the pronunciation in Egypt is  and in Central East Arabia . |group=lower-roman}} 'the recitation'), also romanized '''Qur'an** or **Koran**, The form **Koran** was most predominant from the second half of the 18th century till the 1980s, when it has been superseded by either **Qur'an** or **Quran'*. Other transliterations include *al-Coran*, *Coran*, *Kuran* and *al-Qur'an*. The adjectives vary as well and include *Koranic*, *Quranic* and *Qur'anic'' (sometimes in lowercase).

|group=lower-roman}} is the central [text](religious)(religious text) of [Islam](Islam), believed by [Muslim](Muslim)s to be a [revelation](revelation in Islam) from [God](God in Islam). It is organized in 114 [chapters](surah) (pl.:  , sing.:  ), which consist of [verses](āyah) (pl.:  , sing.:  , [cons.](construct case): ). In addition to its religious significance, it is widely regarded as the finest work in [literature](Arabic)(Arabic literature), and has significantly influenced the [language](Arabic)(Arabic language).

Muslims believe that the Quran was orally revealed by God to the [prophet](final)(Khatam an-Nabiyyin), [Muhammad](Muhammad in Islam), through the archangel [Gabriel](Gabriel) incrementally over a period of some 23 years, beginning on [Al Qadr](Laylat)(Night of Power),[Quran 97:1-5](https://quran.com/97) when Muhammad was 40; and concluding in 632, the year of his death. Muslims regard the Quran as Muhammad's most important [miracle](miracle), a proof of his [prophethood](prophethood); and the culmination of a series of divine messages starting with those revealed to [Adam](Adam in Islam), including the [Tawrat](Tawrat), the [Zabur](Zabur) ([Psalms](Psalms)) and the [Injil](Injil) (Gospel). The word *Quran* occurs some 70 times in the text itself, and other names and words are also said to refer to the Quran.

The Quran is believed by Muslims to be not simply divinely inspired, but the literal [of God](word)(Biblical inspiration). Muhammad did not write it as he did not know how to write. In Muslim theology, the Qur'an is considered to be either "[created](Quranic createdness)" or "uncreated".[*Ibn Ḥanbal and the Miḥna*, 1897](Patton,)(#WMP1897): p.54 According to tradition, several of Muhammad's [companions](Companions of the Prophet) served as scribes, recording the revelations. Shortly after the prophet's death, the Quran was compiled by the companions, who had written down or memorized parts of it. Caliph [Uthman](Uthman) established a standard version, now known as the [codex](Uthmanic)(Uthmanic codex), which is generally considered the archetype of the Quran known today. There are, however, [readings](variant)(Qiraʼat), with mostly minor differences in meaning.

The Quran assumes [with major narratives](familiarity)(Biblical and Quranic narratives) recounted in the [Biblical](Books of the Bible) and [scriptures](apocryphal)(Apocrypha). It summarizes some, dwells at length on others and, in some cases, presents alternative accounts and interpretations of events. The Quran describes itself as a book of guidance for humankind ( ). It sometimes offers detailed accounts of specific historical events, and it often emphasizes the moral significance of an event over its narrative sequence. Supplementing the Quran with explanations for some cryptic Quranic narratives, and rulings that also provide the basis for Islamic law in most denominations of Islam, are *[hadith](hadith)s*—oral and written traditions believed to describe words and actions of Muhammad.  During prayers, the Quran is recited only in [Arabic](Arabic).

Someone who has memorized the entire Quran is called a *[hafiz](Hafiz (Quran))*. Ideally, verses are recited with a special kind of [prosody](Prosody (linguistics)) reserved for this purpose, called *[tajwid](tajwid)*. During the month of Ramadan, Muslims typically complete the recitation of the whole Quran during *[tarawih](tarawih)* prayers. In order to extrapolate the meaning of a particular Quranic verse, Muslims rely on [exegesis](exegesis), or commentary rather than a direct translation of the text.

# Jeff Bauman

*Revision ID: 1160184428 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T22:26:07Z*

---

| birth_place        = Chelmsford, [Massachusetts](Massachusetts), U.S.

**Jeff Bauman** (born January 2, 1986) is an American author. He lost both of his legs during the [Marathon Bombing](Boston)(Boston Marathon Bombing) attack in 2013 and was the subject of a famous photograph taken in the aftermath of the bombing. The film *[Stronger](Stronger (film))* is based on a memoir of the same name he co-wrote, with actor [Gyllenhaal](Jake)(Jake Gyllenhaal) portraying Bauman.
Jeff Bauman's daughter born in 2014 is named Nora Gail Bauman.
